articles.title: Neanderthals mastered fire — 400,000 years ago
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04059-4Archaeological evidence makes a compelling case for Neanderthal-created fires 400,000 years ago in Suffolk, UK — plus, how chatbots can sway the opinions of voters.
articles.content:
Archaeological evidence makes a compelling case for Neanderthal-created fires 400,000 years ago in Suffolk, UK — plus, how chatbots can sway the opinions of voters.

You have full access to this article via your institution.

Download the Nature Podcast 10 December 2025

In this episode:

00:46 Evidence of the earliest fire

Baked soil, ancient tools and materials that could be used to start fires show that Neanderthals were making fire in the UK 400,000 years ago — the earliest evidence of this skill found so far. Ancient humans are known to have used naturally occurring fires, but evidence of deliberate fire-starting has been hard to come by. A new suite of evidence pushes back the date of fire mastery by 350,000 years. The team behind the finding believes it helps create a more nuanced picture of Neanderthals, who perhaps gathered round fires and told stories in ancient Europe.

Research Article: Davis et al.

News and Views: Oldest known evidence of the controlled ignition of fire

11:31 Research Highlights

Machine-learning algorithms can help to identify traces of life in ancient rocks — plus, why paintings containing a vivid green pigment lose their lustre over time.

Research Highlight: AI finds signs of life in ancient rocks

Research Highlight: The mystery of emerald green — cracked

13:55 How AI chatbots can sway voters with ease

Research suggests that artificial-intelligence chatbots can influence voters’ political views and have a bigger effect than conventional campaigning and advertising. One study found that chatbot conversations swung participants’ candidate preferences by up to 15 percentage points, while another revealed that the chatbots’ effectiveness stems from their ability to synthesize a lot of information in a conversational way.

Nature: AI chatbots can sway voters with remarkable ease — is it time to worry?

articles.personality_title: Neanderthals controlled fire 400,000 years ago, new evidence shows
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long known that early humans used natural fires, but proof that Neanderthals could start and control fire themselves has been hard to find. This skill is important because it helped with cooking, warmth, and protection.

**What happened** – Archaeologists discovered signs of fire use by Neanderthals in Suffolk, UK, dating back 400,000 years. They found baked soil, ancient tools, and materials that could have been used to make fire. This is the oldest clear evidence that Neanderthals were able to create and manage fire.

**Impact** – This discovery pushes back the known date of controlled fire use by about 350,000 years. It changes how we think about Neanderthals, showing they had complex skills. It also suggests they might have gathered around fires to share stories, much like modern humans do.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue searching for more evidence to better understand how Neanderthals used fire in daily life. This may help explain how early humans survived and evolved in different environments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New findings reveal Neanderthals mastered fire 400,000 years ago, reshaping our view of their intelligence and culture.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les Néandertaliens maîtrisaient le feu il y a 400 000 ans, selon de nouvelles preuves
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savaient que les premiers humains utilisaient le feu naturel, mais il était difficile de prouver que les Néandertaliens pouvaient eux-mêmes allumer et contrôler le feu. Cette capacité est importante car elle aidait à cuisiner, à se réchauffer et à se protéger.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des archéologues ont découvert en Suffolk, au Royaume-Uni, des traces d’utilisation du feu par les Néandertaliens datant de 400 000 ans. Ils ont trouvé du sol cuit, des outils anciens et des matériaux pouvant servir à allumer un feu. C’est la plus ancienne preuve claire que les Néandertaliens savaient créer et gérer le feu.

**Impact** – Cette découverte recule de 350 000 ans la date connue de la maîtrise du feu. Elle change notre regard sur les Néandertaliens, montrant qu’ils avaient des compétences complexes. Cela suggère aussi qu’ils pouvaient se rassembler autour du feu pour raconter des histoires, comme les humains modernes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront à chercher plus de preuves pour mieux comprendre comment les Néandertaliens utilisaient le feu dans leur vie quotidienne. Cela pourrait expliquer comment les premiers humains ont survécu et évolué dans différents environnements.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouvelles découvertes montrent que les Néandertaliens maîtrisaient le feu il y a 400 000 ans, transformant notre vision de leur intelligence et de leur culture.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas pruebas muestran que los Neandertales controlaban el fuego hace 400,000 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben que los primeros humanos usaban incendios naturales, pero ha sido difícil probar que los Neandertales podían encender y controlar el fuego por sí mismos. Esta habilidad es importante porque ayudaba a cocinar, calentarse y protegerse.

**Qué pasó** – Arqueólogos encontraron en Suffolk, Reino Unido, señales de uso de fuego por Neandertales hace 400,000 años. Descubrieron suelo quemado, herramientas antiguas y materiales que podrían haber servido para encender fuego. Esta es la evidencia más antigua de que los Neandertales podían crear y manejar el fuego.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo adelanta en 350,000 años la fecha conocida del uso controlado del fuego. Cambia cómo pensamos sobre los Neandertales, mostrando que tenían habilidades complejas. También sugiere que podrían haberse reunido alrededor del fuego para contar historias, como los humanos modernos.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán buscando más evidencia para entender mejor cómo usaban el fuego en su vida diaria. Esto podría ayudar a explicar cómo sobrevivieron y evolucionaron los primeros humanos en diferentes lugares.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Nuevos hallazgos revelan que los Neandertales dominaron el fuego hace 400,000 años, cambiando nuestra visión sobre su inteligencia y cultura.
